Course Description: The objective of this course is to provide introduction to network science, an emerging interdisciplinary discipline with applications to vario

Prerequisites.Desirable: Graph theory fundamentals, algorithms and programming (Desirable)

Course Outcomes.CO1: Students are able to explain basic concepts of network science (random networks, scale free networks, network evolution, robustness and community structure).
Course Outcomes.CO2: Students are able to model and implement computation of network properties from empirical data.
Course Outcomes.CO3: Students are able to analyze and visualize networks.
Course Outcomes.CO4: Students are able to tweak and design algorithms to answer specific questions.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Complex systems and network models, Characteristics of network science, Societal impact, Examples of applications
Graph Theory: Graph theory and origin of networks, Adjacency matrix, Weighted Networks, Bipartite networks, Network Metrics
Graph Theory: Paths and distances, Connectedness, Clustering Coefficient
Random networks: Random network model, Degree distribution, Small worlds
The Scale-Free Property-I: Power laws and scale-free networks, Hubs, The meaning of scale free, Ultra-small property
The Scale-Free Property-II: Role of degree exponent, Generating networks with arbitrary degree exponents
The Barabasi-Albert Model-I: Growth and preferrential attachment, The Barabasi-Albert model, Measuring preferrential attachment.
The Barabasi-Albert Model-II: Non-linear preferrential attachment, The origins of preferrential attachment, | CO1, CO2, CO3, CO4
Evolving Networks: The Bianconi-Barabasi model, Measuring fitness, Bose-Einstein condensation, Evolving networks
Degree Correlations: Assortativity and disassortativity, Measuring degree correlations, Generating correlated networks, The impact of degree correlations
Network Robustness: Percolation theory, Robustness of scale-free networks, Attack tolerence, Cascading failures, Modeling cascading failures, Building robustness
Communities: Basics of communities, Hierarchical clustering, Modularity, Overlapping communities, Testing communities, Characterizing communities
Spreading phenomena: Epidemic Modeling, Network epidemics, Contact networks, Beyond degree distribution, Immunization, Epidemic prediction

Resource Material.Textbook: Network Science, Albert-Laszlo Barabasi (Cambridge University Press)
Resource Material.Reference Book: Network Science, Albert-Laszlo Barabasi (Cambridge University Press)
